WRITING.TITLE: Is Salt Lake City fun for a non-Mormon?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm getting considerably more money on my tax return than I expected and have always wanted to go out west. I spent some time searching flights today and SLC is one of the cheaper flights I could find. I'm a practicing Catholic but I've very recently become interested in the LDS movement on an academic/general interest level and thought it'd be interesting to see where the church is headquartered. However, I don't want to just see church related stuff if I go. I love getting into a city, doing non-touristy things, eating where the locals eat, so I'd like to get some advice on the city itself. Are there fun activities for non-Mormons? I'm hopefully planning to travel in May or July. I have a pretty decent budget to work with and I'm a history teacher so museums and historic sites are a win-win. Anything relating to food too, and maybe some bars (I know, bars in Utah are weird but figured I try). Feel free to suggest church related stuff too. Thanks!

The Dalai Lama has said in the past that he himself (the 14th of course) might be "The last Dalai Lama." Could you expand a bit on the sentiments behind this statement and how you think Tibet itself would react if this centuries-old institution were suddenly to end?

The origin of the meal itself is murky. But the word "brunch" was coined by Guy Beringer in 1895 in an article entitled "Brunch: A Plea" in a periodical called Hunter's Weekly. He claimed it as a meal for "Saturday night carousers." http://books.google.com/books?id=l015C5vm1XkC amp;pg=PA99 amp;dq=brunch+%22Guy+beringer%22#v=onepage amp;q=brunch%20%22Guy%20beringer%22 amp;f=false

WRITING.TITLE: What was everyday life like for the French under the German military occupation (1940-44)?
WRITING.TEXT: I've researched WWII pretty extensively, but have never really delved into the ins and outs of the military administration in France (I'm more interested in the Russian front). I know about the blitz and the subsequent fall of the third republic, but what was the impact on the French people in their day to day lives? Was collaboration widespread? Why wasn't there a larger resistance effort? Feel free to recommend books and articles as well.

I'm fairly new to reddit and to this sub in general, but just want to say I'm really enjoying it so far! Anyway, I've been obsessed with Mormonism recently. I finished up with Matthew Bowman's *The Mormon People: The Making of an American Faith* and I'm currently working on Richard Lyman Bushman's *Joseph Smith: Rough Stone Rolling*. I have to say it's one of the more engaging biographies I've come across in quite some time. It's one of the few volumes you're likely to find on a professional historian's shelf as well as a practicing member of the LDS church. Bushman does an excellent job of weaving Joseph's story into the larger fabric of religious experience in the early 1800's and, in doing so, describes the development of early Mormon doctrine. If anybody else has read it, I welcome your thoughts. I'd also like to request any other recommendations on LDS history, biography or otherwise.

There's a particularly great firsthand account called *My Reminiscences of East Africa* by Lt. Col. Paul Emil Von Lettow-Vorbeck, who led the German East African Campaign. It's not an overall study of the African theatre, but if you want to read about how a few thousand Germans and Africans led one of the most successful guerrilla campaigns of all time then I highly recommend it.

A while back I did a study on the historiography of the Russian Revolution. Unsurprisingly, during the Cold War, you had the pro-Soviet camp and the pro-Western camp. More recently, there've been the revisionist historiographers who try to view the revolution through different analytical approaches. Since I've been away from it for a while, I was wondering if anybody could explain or list some newer approaches or authors?

WRITING.TITLE: Pokemon + Attack on Titan. Kinda funny, mostly terrifying
Latin mass guide?
WRITING.TEXT: So I'm curious and really really want to go to my first Latin mass. Luckily, I live in central PA and the diocese of Harrisburg has a Latin mass community that celebrates high mass every Sunday. But the more I look into it, the more daunting it seems. Are there any resources on what to do/say during the course of the mass? A step by step guide? If I can't completely understand it, is it going to be as spiritually fulfilling?
Harrisburg is a bit closer so I'm planning on going to their St. Lawrence Chapel in a few weeks, but I'll be sure to wake up extra early and make it to Lancaster this summer!
That's interesting seeing as it was never technically "banned."

WRITING.TITLE: Dipping "stereotypes"
WRITING.TEXT: Just for background, I grew up around chew. My dad does it, my bro, few of my frat brothers. So it was always around. First tried when I got into managing my HS baseball team. Apart from that, I do theatre, love anime, write poems, and I currently teach religion at a catholic high school. I also look like a red headed long lost member of weezer: thick black glasses, mostly dress in button up shirts, skinny corduroys/jeans. The whole "stereotype" thing came in when I went this past week for a bachelor party in Kentucky and went to a corner store in Louisville. I swear the cashier started reaching for American Spirits before I said "No I want a can of Cope Mint." He just looked at me haha. Just wondering if anybody else doesn't fit the script. If you do, that's fine but I never really thought it was so prevalent!

I dip and I'm on the left (I don't say liberal because I feel both sides are the same). But I agree with ya. Half the time I got buddies that say it's gross or whatever then turn around and light up their cancer sticks without a second thought. Go figure.
Whoa this happened to me when I was picking up my weekly box once!
I'm your brother in dip. But fuck Man U Keep the Blue Flag Flting High! Chelsea!!!
Um I am a Teke. We're different everywhere you go. Don't judge all chapters based on one. Till you go to a conference. You're literally talking to your chapter, not much else.
I love this.
I do cope mint but I got my legs on grizz. Also I drive a Beamer. But I blast black flag and Descendents out of it
I like Metal as well. Grew up punk but I float between the scenes. Who do you like metal wise currently?
Can you link me to your bands? Would love to hear some old school punk while packing a lip!
No matter where you go in PA dip is CHEAP. I've never paid over 3 bucks.
Glock as well. Occasionally I'll keep my kimber in the glove box

WRITING.TITLE: WWI recommendation
WRITING.TEXT: A friend of mine have a bit of a pact this new year. We both work at a book store and while preparing a leading list for the coming months we said we #8217;d pick a book for each other. She reads mostly fiction so that #8217;ll be my lot but she knows very little about WWI and that happens to be one of my favorite areas of study and I need a recommendation on a WWI book to sort of #8220;introduce #8221; the war to my friend. My only limitations are that it can #8217;t be #8220;too academic #8221; #8220;not real real thick. #8221; I don #8217;t wanna get just a dry #8220;here #8217;s a bunch of facts #8221; kind of thing so maybe a more popular history, written for general audiences? If anyone has any suggestions I #8217;m all ears!

WRITING.TITLE: Interfaith experiences?
WRITING.TEXT: It sounds a bit cliche but I #8217;ve found my interfaith experiences to be highly enriching. Full background/disclosure, I consider myself a bit of a trad liturgically (I like my Latin, my incense, etc.) but identify strongly with the Catholic Worker and volunteer with them extensively. But getting back on subject, I #8217;ve been to a synagogue, mosque, even a Buddhist thing and leaving all of them found myself more dedicated to the faith than ever. Just curious on hearing about your interfaith experiences. (Funny enough, have never had the same experience at any Protestant places of worship.)

Thank you so much for posting this! I love learning about Christianity in Japan. I did a bit of digging on this rebellion and surprisingly there #8217;s only one decent scholarly study on it titled [Christ #8217;s Samurai: The True Story of the Shimabara Rebellion](https://www.amazon.com/Christs-Samurai-Story-Shimabara-Rebellion-ebook/dp/B012E3LPM2/ref=nodl_) by Jonathan Clements. Had to buy a copy ASAP! It #8217;s amazing the amount of attention given to the stories of Christians in Japan and the rest of the Far East in the last couple of years. Even when I took History of Japan at college (in 2008), it was only lightly mentioned and the historiography left a lot to be desired. I wonder if they #8217;ve been considered for canonization as martyrs?

WRITING.TITLE: Annulments
WRITING.TEXT: First off, I #8217;m unmarried. But my brother was married in the church over a year ago. His wife left him after a few months. He #8217;s moved on and is doing fine but he #8217;s applied for an annulment. He #8217;s been going back to mass and I #8217;m overjoyed at this. I #8217;ve been a faithful son of the Church for my entire life but annulments remain a point of confusion. They never really came up in my theology classes at university either. Are there any resources to learn more about this according to Canon Law in plain terms? Does every annulment really go all the way to the Rota? Anything is appreciated.
